title: Clustering and viewing GSEA results
text: Similar ORA, GSEA enrichment analysis (GSEA enrichment analysis? See webpage: https://yulab-smu.top/biomedical-knowledge-mining-book/enrichment-overview.html), EnrichGT can read results gseaResult generated clusterProfiler exported table clusterProfiler enrichment (including least columns “ID”,“Description”,“NES”,“pvalue”,“p.adjust” “core_enrichment”. EnrichGT performs term frequency statistics automatic clustering based genes enriched hits, returns S4 object, outputs beautifully formatted result wrapped gt.

title: Clustering and viewing GSEA results
text: shows results. detailing usage, please see Article ORA (article). encourage run clusterProfiler::setReadable() first passing EnrichGT(), get gene symbols correctly (bad example without setReadable()).  setReadable() run:
code: suppressMessages({   library(tidyverse)   library(gt)   library(clusterProfiler)   library(org.Hs.eg.db)   }) data(geneList, package="DOSE") ego3 <- gseGO(geneList     = geneList,                 OrgDb        = org.Hs.eg.db,                 ont          = "CC",                 minGSSize    = 100,                 maxGSSize    = 500,                 pvalueCutoff = 0.05,                 verbose      = FALSE) #> Warning in fgseaMultilevel(pathways = pathways, stats = stats, minSize = #> minSize, : For some pathways, in reality P-values are less than 1e-10. You can #> set the `eps` argument to zero for better estimation. (EnrichGT(ego3, ClusterNum = 100, P.adj = 1)@gt_object) #> Loading required package: proxy #>  #> Attaching package: 'proxy' #> The following object is masked from 'package:IRanges': #>  #>     as.matrix #> The following object is masked from 'package:S4Vectors': #>  #>     as.matrix #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     as.dist, dist #> The following object is masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     as.matrix #> Loading required package: text2vec #>  #> Attaching package: 'text2vec' #> The following object is masked from 'package:BiocGenerics': #>  #>     normalize #> [Message]Please run setReadable first! #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` ego3<-ego3 |> setReadable(OrgDb = org.Hs.eg.db,keyType = "ENTREZID") (EnrichGT(ego3, ClusterNum = 100, P.adj = 1)@gt_object) #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)`

title: Clustering and viewing GSEA results
Clustering and viewing compareClusterResult
text: EnrichGT supports compareClusterResult data.frame column “Cluster” containing group informations.         Return list containing EnrichGT_obj compareClusterResult.
code: suppressMessages({   library(tidyverse)   library(gt)   library(clusterProfiler)   library(org.Hs.eg.db)   }) data(gcSample) ck <- compareCluster(geneCluster = gcSample, fun = enrichGO, OrgDb = org.Hs.eg.db, pvalueCutoff = 0.5, qvalueCutoff = 0.5,ont="BP") ck <- setReadable(ck, OrgDb = org.Hs.eg.db, keyType = "ENTREZID") sd <- EnrichGT(ck, ClusterNum = 3, P.adj = 1) #> Loading required package: proxy #>  #> Attaching package: 'proxy' #> The following object is masked from 'package:IRanges': #>  #>     as.matrix #> The following object is masked from 'package:S4Vectors': #>  #>     as.matrix #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     as.dist, dist #> The following object is masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     as.matrix #> Loading required package: text2vec #>  #> Attaching package: 'text2vec' #> The following object is masked from 'package:BiocGenerics': #>  #>     normalize #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> [Message]Too many rows! It might be slow... Working, but please consider #> increase P.adj ... #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` str(sd,max.level=3) #> List of 8 #>  $ X1:Formal class 'EnrichGT_obj' [package "EnrichGT"] with 4 slots #>   .. ..@ enriched_result : tibble [30 × 7] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. ..@ gt_object       :List of 17 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "gt_tbl" "list" #>   .. ..@ gene_modules    :List of 3 #>   .. ..@ pathway_clusters:List of 3 #>  $ X2:Formal class 'EnrichGT_obj' [package "EnrichGT"] with 4 slots #>   .. ..@ enriched_result : tibble [30 × 7] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   .. ..@ gt_object   .. ..@ gene_modules    :List of 3 #>   .. ..@ pathway_clusters:List of 3 #>  $ X4:Formal class 'EnrichGT_obj' [package "EnrichGT"] with 4 slots #>   .. ..@ enriched_result : tibble [30 × 7] (S3: title: Clustering and viewing compareClusterResult
Clustering and viewing ORA results
text: overexpression enrichment analysis (overexpression enrichment analysis? See webpage: https://yulab-smu.top/biomedical-knowledge-mining-book/enrichment-overview.html), EnrichGT can read results enrichResult generated clusterProfiler exported table clusterProfiler enrichment (including least columns “ID”, “Description”, “GeneRatio”, “pvalue”, “p.adjust”, “geneID” “Count”). EnrichGT performs term frequency statistics automatic clustering based genes enriched hits, returns S4 object, outputs beautifully formatted result wrapped gt.

title: Clustering and viewing ORA results
code: suppressMessages({   library(tidyverse)   library(gt)   library(clusterProfiler)   library(org.Hs.eg.db)   }) data(geneList, package="DOSE") gene <- names(geneList)[abs(geneList) > 2] ego <- enrichGO(gene          = gene,                   universe      = names(geneList),                   OrgDb         = org.Hs.eg.db,                   ont           = "BP",                   pAdjustMethod = "BH",                   pvalueCutoff  = 0.5,                   qvalueCutoff  = 0.5,                   readable      = TRUE)

title: Clustering and viewing ORA results
text: can define many clusters many top terms shown. can adjust p-adj cut-.
code: ego #> # #> # over-representation test #> # #> #...@organism     Homo sapiens  #> #...@ontology     BP  #> #...@keytype      ENTREZID  #> #...@gene     chr [1:207] "4312" "8318" "10874" "55143" title: Clustering and viewing ORA results
text: created obj contains several slots: Simply enter obj console also can returns rendered gt view viewer plane RStudio. gt object storaged gt_object. can use gt functions like gt::gtsave() calling obj@gt_object. Full enriched enriched (enrich^2) result obj@enriched_result. also generated gene modules pathway clusters based clustering results. can assess obj@gene_modules obj@pathway_clusters.
code: str(obj,max.level=2) #> Formal class 'EnrichGT_obj' [package "EnrichGT"] with 4 slots #>   ..@ enriched_result : tibble [34 × 7] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   ..@ gt_object       :List of 17 #>   .. ..- attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "gt_tbl" "list" #>   ..@ gene_modules    :List of 7 #>   ..@ pathway_clusters:List of 7 obj obj@gt_object df1<-obj@enriched_result |> as_tibble() df1 #> # A tibble: 34 × 7 #>    Description                         ID    Count Cluster   PCT     Padj geneID #>    <chr>                               <chr> <int> <chr>   <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>  #>  1 nuclear chromosome segregation      GO:0…    33 Cluste…    17 6.70e-18 CDCA8… #>  2 chromosome segregation              GO:0…    37 Cluste…    19 6.70e-18 CDCA8… #>  3 mitotic sister chromatid segregati… GO:0…    27 Cluste…    14 2.10e-17 CDCA8… #>  4 sister chromatid segregation        GO:0…    29 Cluste…    15 2.20e-17 CDCA8… #>  5 mitotic nuclear division            GO:0…    31 Cluste…    16 4.10e-17 CDCA8… #>  6 nuclear division                    GO:0…    36 Cluste…    18 5.30e-17 CDCA8… #>  7 organelle fission                   GO:0…    37 Cluste…    19 1.7 e-16 CDCA8… #>  8 microtubule cytoskeleton organizat… GO:1…    23 Cluste…    12 1.9 e-14 CDCA8… #>  9 chromosome organization             GO:0…    38 Cluste…    19 1.4 e-13 CDC45… #> 10 cell division                       GO:0…    37 Cluste…    19 2.5 e-12 CDCA8… #> # ℹ 24 more rows head(obj@gene_modules) #> $Cluster_1 #>  [1] "ASPM"     "AURKA"    "AURKB"    "BIRC5"    "BMP4"     "CCNA2"    #>  [7] "CCNB1"    "CCNB2"    "CDC20"    "CDC45"    "CDCA3"    "CDCA8"    #> [13] "CDK1"     "CDT1"     "CENPE"    "CENPM"    "CENPN"    "CEP55"    #> [19] "CHEK1"    "DLGAP5"   "E2F8"     "ERCC6L"   "EZH2"     "GINS1"    #> [25] "GINS2"    "HJURP"    "KIF11"    "KIF18A"   "KIF18B"   "KIF20A"   #> [31] "KIF23"    "KIF4A"    "KIFC1"    "MAD2L1"   "MAPT"     "MCM5"     #> [37] "MYBL2"    "NCAPG"    "NCAPH"    "NDC80"    "NEK2"     "NUSAP1"   #> [43] "PAX6"     "PRC1"     "PTTG1"    "RAD51AP1" "SKA1"     "TACC3"    #> [49] "TOP2A"    "TPX2"     "TRIP13"   "TTK"      "UBE2C"    "UBE2S"    #>  #> $Cluster_2 #>  [1] "ASPM"     "AURKA"    "AURKB"    "CCNA2"    "CCNB1"    "CCNB2"    #>  [7] "CDC20"    "CDC45"    "CDK1"     "CDT1"     "CHAF1B"   "CHEK1"    #> [13] "DACH1"    "DTL"      "E2F8"     "FOXM1"    "GINS1"    "GINS2"    #> [19] "KIF18A"   "MCM10"    "MCM5"     "MELK"     "NCAPH"    "NDC80"    #> [25] "NEK2"     "PGR"      "PTTG1"    "RAD51AP1" "RRM2"     "TOP2A"    #> [31] "TRIP13"   "TTK"      #>  #> $Cluster_3 #>  [1] "ACKR1"  "C7"     "CAMP"   "CCL18"  "CCL8"   "CX3CR1" "CXCL10" "CXCL11" #>  [9] "CXCL13" "CXCL14" "CXCL9"  "GATA3"  "GNLY"   "HMGCS2" "IDO1"   "INAVA"  #> [17] "MAOB"   "PCK1"   "RNASE4" "S100A7" "S100A8" "S100A9" "SLC7A5" #>  #> $Cluster_4 #> [1] "BMP4"   "GATA3"  "NDP"    "PAX6"   "PLAAT1" #>  #> $Cluster_6 #>  [1] "CENPE"  "CFAP69" "DLGAP5" "KIF11"  "KIF18A" "KIF18B" "KIF20A" "KIF23"  #>  [9] "KIF4A"  "KIFC1"  "MAPT"   "TRIM58" #>  #> $Cluster_7 #> [1] "ADIPOQ" "AURKB"  "CCNA2"  "CHEK1"  "DACH1"  "NEK2"

title: Clustering and viewing ORA results
Get Start
text: First enrich genes clusterProfiler… , run obj |> EnrichGT() !  guidance, see Articles.
code: ego <- enrichGO(gene          = gene,                   universe      = names(geneList),                   OrgDb         = org.Hs.eg.db,                   ont           = "BP",                   pAdjustMethod = "BH",                   pvalueCutoff  = 0.5,                   qvalueCutoff  = 0.5,                   readable      = TRUE) obj <- ego |> EnrichGT() #>  #> =====[SUGGESTION]===== #> You are passing an object from GO Enrichment. #> Please ensure that `obj |> clusterProfiler::simplify()` is executed, to pre-simplify result, #> For better enriched result. #> Loading required package: proxy #>  #> Attaching package: 'proxy' #> The following object is masked from 'package:IRanges': #>  #>     as.matrix #> The following object is masked from 'package:S4Vectors': #>  #>     as.matrix #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     as.dist, dist #> The following object is masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     as.matrix #> Loading required package: text2vec #>  #> Attaching package: 'text2vec' #> The following object is masked from 'package:BiocGenerics': #>  #>     normalize #> Joining with `by = join_by(ID)` obj@gt_object

title: Get Start
Authors and Citation
text: Zhiming Ye. Maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ye Z (2024). EnrichGT: Parse cluster biological enrichment result great tables. R package version 0.2.3, https://zhimingye.github.io/EnrichGT/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {EnrichGT: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables},   author = {Zhiming Ye},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.2.3},   url = {https://zhimingye.github.io/EnrichGT/}, }

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
code: library(devtools) install_github("ZhimingYe/EnrichGT")

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: Please see Articles examples help.

what: Challenges in Biological Gene Enrichment Analysis
title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: Gene enrichment analysis can often misleading due redundancy within gene set databases limitations enrichment tools. Many tools, default, display top results fail filter redundancy. can result biological misinterpretation valuable information overlooked. instance, high expression certain immune genes can cause many immune-related gene sets appear overrepresented. However, closer look often reveals gene sets derived group genes, might represent small fraction (less 10%) differentially expressed genes (DEGs). 90%? hold biological significance?

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: EnrichGT based clusterProfiler. clusterProfiler one powerful tools R enrichment analysis. ’s designed pathway redundancy mind includes clusterProfiler::simplify function address issue. method, based GOSemSim GO similarity evaluation, scientifically robust highly effective. However, drawbacks: GOSemSim fast, particularly dealing large complex gene sets. doesn’t support databases like KEGG Reactome. Using GOSemSim measure semantic similarity pathways , theoretically, best way tackle redundancy. However, practical cases—especially experimental bioinformatics validation—researchers focused genes behind pathways rather pathways .

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: Although clustering pathways based gene overlap received criticism, remains viable approach many situations. reason, developed BioThemeFinder years ago solve problem. However, tool awful (poor coding…) Today, two excellent alternatives exist: simplifyEnrichment: package scientifically rigorous (based semantic similarity) creates beautiful visualizations. aPEAR: simpler faster tool better aligns practical needs, making preferred choice. However, tools common limitation: visualizations optimized publication purposes rather exploratory research. often find exporting CSV files struggling RStudio’s preview pane fully explore enrichment tables. inspired develop efficient solution.

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: main purpose developing package provide lightweight practical solution problems mentioned . Specifically, package aims : Cluster enrichment results based hit genes core enrichment GSEA using term frequency analysis (output powerful clusterProfiler. provides clearer view biological relevance focusing genes matter . Visualize results using Posit PBC gt package, offers two key advantages: Improved readability compared traditional tables, making easier interpret results. HTML-based output allows internal searching filtering, making exploration user-friendly. Seamless Integration Publishing Tools : Another significant advantage using gt package seamless integration modern publishing systems like Rmarkdown quarto. ensures results can easily shared published professional format, also allowing interactive exploration research phase. ’re tired redundant pathways cluttering enrichment results spending much time computational bottlenecks, package help.

title: Build up a DEG data frame for clusterProfiler multi-group ORA analysis — BuildMultigroupDEGlist
text: Zhiming Ye

what: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: Parse enrichment results clustering visualizing

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
code: EnrichGT(x, ClusterNum = 15, P.adj = 0.05, force = F, nTop = 20, ...)

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: x enrichment result `clusterProfiler`, `data.frame` containing result `clusterProfier` ClusterNum many cluster clustered P.adj p.adjust cut-. avoid slow visualization, can make stricter p-cut . force ignore auto-self-checks, useful nTop keep n top items according p-adj cluster. ... Others options.

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: `EnrichGT_obj` object. slot `enriched_result` contains data.frame enriched results. `gt_object` contains `gt` object. can use `obj@gt_object` get use functions `gt` like `gtsave`. `gene_modules` list containing meta-gene modules cluster. `pathway_clusters` contains pathways names cluster.

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: ORA result, c("ID","Description","GeneRatio","pvalue","p.adjust","geneID","Count") contained; GSEA, c("ID","Description","NES","pvalue","p.adjust","core_enrichment") contain. `compareClusterResult`, `compareClusterResult` object data-frame additional `Cluster` column contained, others similar ORA result.

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: Zhiming Ye

what: Return ranked gene list which is use for
title: Return ranked gene list which is use for
text: Return ranked gene list use "GSEA" "cnetplot" package "clusterProfiler"

title: Return ranked gene list which is use for
code: Ranked.GS(Gene, log2FC, FromType = "SYMBOL", OrgDB = org.Hs.eg.db)
